name.text: 16.2.1.5 Convergence of the alternating harmonic series

questiontext.text:
As with the harmonic series we shall group the terms of the alternating harmonic series, this time to display its convergence. 

The alternating harmonic series is:

\[ S = 1 - \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{1}{3} - \dfrac{1}{4} + \dfrac{1}{5} - \dots\]

This series may be re-grouped in two distinct ways. 


1st re-grouping

\[ S = 1 - \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{1}{3} - \dfrac{1}{4} + \dfrac{1}{5} + \dots = 1 - \left(\dfrac{1}{2} - \dfrac{1}{3} \right) - \left( \dfrac{1}{4} - \dfrac{1}{5} \right) - \left(  \dfrac{1}{6} - \dfrac{1}{7}\right) - \dots\]

Each term in brackets is positive since \(\dfrac{1}{2}> \dfrac{1}{3}\), \(\dfrac{1}{4}>\dfrac{1}{5}\) and so on. So we easily conclude that \( S< 1\) since we are subtracting only positive numbers from \(1\). 


2nd re-grouping

\[ S = 1 - \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{1}{3} - \dfrac{1}{4} + \dfrac{1}{5} + \dots = \left(1 - \dfrac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{3} - \dfrac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{5} - \dfrac{1}{6}\right) + \dots \]

Again, each term in brackets is positive since \(1 > \dfrac{1}{2}\) , \(\dfrac{1}{3} > \dfrac{1}{4}\) , \(\dfrac{1}{5} > \dfrac{1}{6}\) and so on.

So we can also argue that \(S > \dfrac{1}{2}\) since we are adding only positive numbers to the value of the first term, \(\dfrac{1}{2}\) . 


The conclusion that is forced upon us is that \[\dfrac{1}{2}<S<1\] so that the alternating series is convergent since its sum, \(S\), lies in the range \(\dfrac{1}{2} \to 1\). It will be shown in a later Section that \(S = \ln{2} = 0.693\).
